summary: A character reference letter addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan from an unnamed friend of Ghislaine Maxwell, written in support of her bail application. The letter portrays Maxwell in a positive light, emphasizing her character, philanthropic work, and the author's belief in her innocence, while also offering the author's home as collateral for bail.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The central subject of the character reference letter. The author defends her character, details her life history, philanthropic work with the TerraMar Project, and asserts her innocence regarding criminal charges. The letter is written to support her bail application.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's case in the Southern District of New York, to whom this character reference letter is addressed.

connections.description: The author describes knowing Maxwell all her life, sharing personal experiences, common interests, and considers her one of her best friends. The author is providing her home as collateral for Maxwell's bail.

events.title: Maxwell moves to New York
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell came to live in New York to continue her company, Maxwell Corporate Gifts, and subsequently built a new life there.

events.title: Establishment of the TerraMar Project
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell devoted energy and resources to founding the not-for-profit TerraMar Project, focused on ocean conservation.

events.title: UN Sustainable Development Goal 14
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's work with the TerraMar Project is noted as influencing the United Nations in enunciating Sustainable Development Goal 14 regarding ocean conservation.

events.title: Maxwell's arrest and incarceration
events.description: The letter references Maxwell's recent arrest, the criminal charges filed against her, and her current incarceration conditions, including over 150 days of solitary confinement.

events.title: Bail application
events.description: The author is writing this letter to Judge Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application, offering her $1.5 million home as collateral.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The author offers her only property, valued at $1.5 million, as collateral for Ghislaine Maxwell's bail, stating financial ruin would result if forfeited.
The letter asserts that, to the author's knowledge, Maxwell had never been arrested or charged with a crime until the present case.
The author claims Maxwell has been held in solitary confinement for over 150 days under conditions making it difficult to prepare her defense.
Maxwell is described as having lived in the U.S. for almost 30 years and having deep family ties, including a spouse, in the country.
The letter heavily emphasizes Maxwell's philanthropic work, particularly her founding and leadership of the ocean conservation non-profit, the TerraMar Project.
